Chapter Two
R l s for e-government in ﬁnancial regulation and monitoring 2United Nations E-Government Survey 2010
Chapter 2
Roles for e-government
in ﬁnancial regulation
and monitoring
Governments are deploying new information and communi-
cations technology in response to the global nancial crisis.
ese electronic government technologies have the potential
to deliver imaginative options for policy-making processes as
well as for the debates that surround them. For governments,
the current most critical issue is how to rebuild trust in a sys-
tem of nancial weaknesses and governmental responses that
has proved so highly untrustworthy to date. At this time, how-
ever, no one knows what these attempts at rebuilding trust
might consist of, much less what they could possibly achieve
in terms of refashioning the entire nancial system – ideally, a
system with more eective policies in place for nancial regu-
lation and monitoring.
In two historical analogies – the Great Depression and the
Asian nancial crisis – new technology embedded in capital
formation alongside government eorts played some part in
the subsequent stages of recovery. ese historical compari-
sons demonstrate how alike the ‘causes’ of past and present
nancial crises may be, as well as the patterns of circumstances
and behaviours that emerge. Moreover, these comparisons
inform the discussion about the role of new technology and
especially governmentally underpinned technology (such as
rural electrication in the 1930s) in recovery. In the recent
Asian experience, government actually made use of ICT,
which provides the technological backbone of e-government,
to advance recovery.
